title: Artistes take to social media, call for peace
text:
Ruchika M. Khanna
Tribune News Service
Chandigarh, October 17
Punjab’s cultural icons today cautioned the youth not to fall prey to the “politics of religion” even as they expressed their anguish and hurt at the sacrilege of Guru Granth Sahib. These icons, including Gurdas Mann, Harbhajan Mann, Gippy Grewal and Darshan Aulakh, took to the social media to express how deeply they were hurt because of the sacrilege, but asked their followers to exercise restraint and maintain peace. Gurdas Mann posted a short three minute video on YouTube asking people not to lose their “hosh” (mental balance) in “josh”. He warned that people want to destroy Punjab and take it back to the days of terrorism Film actor and producer Darshan Aulakh said: “People’s religious sentiments have been hurt and they are rightfully protesting. But they should not take to violence.” Singer Harbhajan Mann too took to Facebook to address the issue. “Any form of disrespect shown to Guru Granth Sahib is deeply hurting and saddening,” he posted on his Facebook account, asking people to hold peaceful protests. Actor Gippy Grewal too posted that he was disturbed at recent happenings. Efforts should be made to amicably solve the problem, he said.
